subject: Home & DIY
title: The Privacy Cost of Convenience
description: One-minute skill: The Privacy Cost of Convenience.

hook.text: Your speaker always listens. Your TV tracks viewing. Your vacuum maps your floor plan. All that data goes somewhere.

buildup.text: Smart devices collect usage patterns, voice recordings, location data, and readingsâ€”often shared with third parties.

discovery.text: Amazon employs thousands to review Alexa recordings. Google Home has recorded without hearing wake words.

twist.text: Smart home data is gold: insurers could set premiums by your habits, and advertisers can target you by home behavior.

climax.text: Privacy alternatives exist: local voice processing, open-source hubs, and devices that never send data off your network.

punchline.text: Your home knows everything about youâ€”and so might others.

quiz.question: Why are smart home data patterns valuable to third parties?
options: They reveal habits that insurers and advertisers can monetize
They contain personal passwords and financial data
They show when your security system is disarmed
